required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of Spasticity on Glucose Metabolism in Individuals With Spinal Cord Injury
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of Spasticity on Glucose Metabolism and Soft Tissue Body Composition in Individuals With Motor Complete and Motor Incomplete Spinal Cord Injury

lead_sponsor.agency: Fatih Sultan Mehmet Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Fatih Sultan Mehmet Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Muscle atrophy may occur in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) as a result of diminished physical activity and alterations in glucose metabolism and body composition may be seen. In a few studies, it has been suggested that spasticity may have a positive impact on glucose metabolism by preventing muscle atrophy and alterations in body composition in individuals with motor complete SCI. Investigators aimed to assess the effects of spasticity on glucose metabolism and body composition in participants with complete and incomplete SCI.

detailed_description.textblock: Investigators plan a prospective clinical trial. Participants with SCI were included to study if times from injury were at least one year. Participants had an AIS grades of A-D with spasticity. Spasticity was assessed with Penn Spasm Frequency Scale (PSFS), Spinal Cord Assessment Tool for Spastic Reflexes (SCATS) and Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS). Hip adductor and extensor spasticity, knee extensor and flexor spasticity and ankle plantar flexor spasticity were assessed by using MAS. Body composition was measured by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry. All participants underwent a 75 gram (g) oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Insulin sensitivity was assessed by calculating Matsuda index and HOMA-IR. Investigators assessed the effects of spasticity on glucose metabolism and body composition in participants with SCI.

primary_outcome.description: Modified Ashworth Scale is used to asses muscles spasticity on a 6-point scale. 0: No increase in muscle tone 4: Affected part(s) is (are) rigid in flexion or extension.
The Penn Spasm Frequency Scale measures self assessed global spasm frequency on a 5-point scale. 0: no; 5: = spasms occurring more than 10 times per hour.

primary_outcome.measure: Spinal Cord Assessment Tool for Spastic Reflexes (SCATS)
primary_outcome.description: The SCATS assesses the severity of the 3 spasticity components: clonus, flexor spasm, and extensor spasm. These 3 subscales measured with a score of 0 to 3. Clonus is measured by rapid passive dorsiflexion of the ankle. clonic burst was timed and scored as follows: 0, no reaction; 1, the duration was <3 seconds; 2, clonus persisted between 3 and 10 seconds; and 3, clonus lasted >10 seconds. Flexor spasm was measured by applying a pinprick stimulus to the medial arch of the foot. 0, no reaction to stimulus; 1, <10 degree flexion at the hip and knee, or extension of the big toe; 2, 10 to 30 degree flexion of the hip and knee; and 3, >30 degree hip and knee flexion. SCATS extensor spasm was measured by visible quadriceps muscle contraction. This evaluation is same the SCATS clonus.

intervention.description: fat mass % (FM%) and fat-free mass (FFM%)% of arms, legs, trunk, android, gynoid and total body

In the morning after 12 hours overnight fast, all individuals underwent a 75 gram (g) oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Blood samples were taken before loading glucose and then 30, 60, 90 and 120 minutes after taking glucose solution in order to measure serum glucose and insulin levels. Glycohemoglobin (HbA1c) was measured in blood samples taken before the OGTT. We calculated the Matsuda index and Homeostasis model assessment index (HOMA-IR) using glucose and insulin levels.

study_pop.textblock: Individuals with SCI were included to study if they were 18-65 years old and times from injury were at least one year.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
• Spinal cord injury AIS A,B,C,D
Exclusion Criteria:
- Other central nervous system diseases
- Significant complications that affect spasticity
- Joint contracture
- Diabetes mellitus

overall_official.affiliation: Fatih Sultan Mehmet Training and Research Hospital
